awd_titl_txt: Elements: NSCI-Software -- A General and Effective B-Spline R-Matrix Package for Charged-Particle and Photon Collisions with Atoms, Ions, and Molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
This project concerns the development and subsequent distribution of a suite of computer codes that can accurately describe the interaction of charged particles (mostly electrons) and light (mostly lasers and synchrotrons) with atoms and ions. The results are of importance for the understanding of fundamental collision dynamics, and they also fulfill the urgent practical need for accurate atomic data to model the physics of stars, plasmas, lasers, and planetary atmospheres. With the rapid advances currently seen in computational resources, such studies can now be conducted for realistic systems, as opposed to idealized models. In particular, it has become possible to describe very complex targets, such as transition metals and other open-shell systems. Examples include the excited states of the inert gases beyond helium, as well as neutral and lowly-ionized iron.  These systems are of significant importance for plasma diagnostics and astrophysics, respectively.  The source code will be made publicly available. The project will support a post-doctoral researcher. A website devoted to user-developer interaction will be developed and maintained together with the neccessary code documentation and training materials.

The numerical calculations will be based upon the non-perturbative R-matrix (close-coupling) method.  A particular strength of the implementation pursued in this project is the use of a highly flexible B-spline basis with non-orthogonal orbital sets.  The major advantage of the approach compared to traditional methods is the fact that an accurate target description can be achieved with a much-reduced configuration-interaction (CI) expansion if the orthogonality requirements on the individual orbitals are relaxed.  This is critical for complex targets, where the valence orbitals in particular are known to be strongly term-dependent. Using a sufficiently small but still accurate enough CI expansion for the target states is essential for the feasibility and quality of the subsequent collision calculation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project concerned the further development and subsequent distribution of the B-spline R-matrix (BSR) suite of computer codes, which can accurately describe the interaction of charged particles (mostly electrons) and light (mostly lasers and synchrotrons) with atoms and ions. In addition to the code development, instructional material to make the program usable by other interested researchers was created.  The project continues by being a vital part of the Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Science Gateway (https://amosgateway.org/home/).

This work is important for fundamental research in the areas of light--matter and charged-particle--matter interactions as well as many applications, particularly in plasma and astrophysics.  The data from our calculations are frequently used in modeling, for example, the energy transport in various environments.  An indication of our impact on many projects worldwide is the large number of collaborations we maintain with groups in North America, Europe, Asia, and Australia.

Over the course of the funding period, three post-doctoral researchers, one visiting graduate student, and two Drake undergraduate students participated in the project. One of the post-doctoral researchers obtained her own tenure-track position at the University of Colorado Denver in 2022, another secured a similar position at Panskura Banamali College in India in 2023, and the third one will continue under another NSF-funded project.  One of the undergraduate students is currently pursuing a doctoral degree at CU-Boulder/JILA while the other has moved into Computer Science. The graduate student came to Drake University in order to broaden his knowledge from time-independent structure physics to time-dependent, dynamic laser-atom interactions.  Given his performance on many projects, he is expected to be offered a prestigious post-doctoral position soon.

All these participants were able to significantly increase their knowledge regarding various aspects of Computational Science, with particular emphasis on Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics.  This included the treatment of challenging problems through the use of supercomputing facilities provided by the NSF-supported eXtreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE) and its successor, the Advanced Cyberinfrastructure Coordination Ecosystem: Services & Suppor (ACCESS).

A total of 24 papers in peer-reviewed scientific journals were published during the funding period.  In addition, the principal investigator gave 7 and one of the post-doctoral researcher 3 invited talks at various international conferences -- some in person, some virtually due to COVID-19 restrictions.  In addition, numerous continruted papers as well as colloquia and seminars were presented. The students also had opportunities to showcase their work through contributed talks and posters at the annual meetings of the Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics.
